case_vignette: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of malaise, dysuria, blurred vision, and a painful, itchy rash. The rash began on her chest and face and spread to her limbs, palms, and soles. One week ago, she was diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia and started on a new medicine. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and ulceration on the tongue and palate. There is no lymphadenopathy. Examination of the skin shows confluent annular, erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation of the palms and soles. The epidermis separates when the skin is lightly stroked.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling generally unwell for 3 days, have pain and a burning sensation when I urinate, my vision is blurry, and I've got a painful, itchy rash.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 56-year-old woman.
Have you had any similar symptoms in the past?
No, I haven't had these symptoms before.
Is the rash localized to one area or spread all over your body?
The rash started on my chest and face and spread to my limbs, palms, and soles.
Have you recently started taking any new medications, or have you been exposed to any new products or allergens?
Yes, I started a new medicine a week ago for facial nerve pain.
Can you tell me the name of the medication you started taking?
I'm sorry, I don't know the name of the medicine.
Do any members of your family have a history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases?
I do not have any information on my family's medical history regarding skin conditions or autoimmune diseases.
Have you experienced any joint pain, swelling, or stiffness recently?
No, I haven't experienced any joint pain, swelling, or stiffness.
Have you experienced any fever, weight changes, or other systemic symptoms?
Yes, I have a fever.
Final Diagnosis: Drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction (possible Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis).

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I've been feeling really unwell, experiencing pain and a burning sensation when I urinate, my vision is blurry, and I have a painful, itchy rash that started on my chest and face and has now spread to my arms, legs, hands, and feet.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for the past 3 days.
Do you have any blisters on or around the rash?
Yes, I have blisters on the rash and also peeling skin on my hands and feet.
Do you have a fever or any flu-like symptoms?
Yes, I have a fever.
Have you started any new medications or come into contact with any new substances or products before these symptoms started?
One week ago, I started on a new medicine for facial nerve pain.
What is the name of the medicine you started taking for facial nerve pain?
I'm sorry, I can't recall the name of the medicine for my facial nerve pain.
Have you ever had similar symptoms before, or have you been diagnosed with any skin conditions in the past?
No, I've never had symptoms like this before or been diagnosed with any skin conditions.
Does anyone in your family have a history of skin conditions, immune system disorders, or similar symptoms?
Not that I'm aware of, no family history of such conditions.

Given the presentation of a rash with blisters and peeling skin, recent medication initiation, fever, and systemic symptoms like blurry vision and pain during urination, the symptoms suggest a severe reaction to a medication.

**Final Diagnosis:** Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) or Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN).
